Well, in general, I believe my position on ORG is that we need a bipartisan and fairly rapid process to work through the options and prepare for the long term health and viability of the ORG system, along with the efforts that are going to be made by ORG, which I am very hopeful about. CARDINAL of the big things I hope to achieve before I leave office is entitlement reform in both major systems. So I tell you, I think that that needs to be done, and we are exploring how best to do that. Well, we do not want to let you off the hook too easily. You are not saying you are against using the surplus to shore up ORG? I am not saying CARDINAL way or the other. I am saying I'd like to have something to announce on State of the Union TIME. That would achieve the aims in theory of raising the cost of a pack of cigarettes by so much that it would be beyond the reach of teenagers, achieve your major aim, and not take companies off the hook for future liability. Are you in favor of such a bill? You'd have a children's only bill that did what? I am sorry, you had a lot of points there.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mara Liasson and Robert Siegel of National Public Radio

text: Yes, well, first, it would raise the price of a pack of cigarettes simply to deter teenage purchasers of cigarettes. Well, I would favor doing something like that without committing to the specifics if we fail to get a global settlement. But I think we owe it to the attorneys general and the others who worked with us on this in good faith to try to achieve one, because I think, long term, we need to deter teen smoking with more than just a higher price tag for cigarettes. I think there are lots of other things that can be done. And I think that we ought to have certain benchmarks of performance for the tobacco companies, too, which in my view will help because then they will be free to do more that they even have to spend a little more money than they are obligated to under the agreement if they are not meeting the targets, they may decide they ought to do that to save even more money down the road. So I am going to look for a global settlement in the tobacco case for the benefit of our children. If we fail, then I will look at something else. ENTITY, following up on that, you have cautioned ORG not to spend the surplus until they have it. Yet you have committed MONEY of some projected tobacco settlement bill before it is even passed to new spending. And if you do not get a tobacco settlement, are you committed to those programs? Will you cut elsewhere in order to keep that new spending? I will not, under any circumstances, favor funding anything I have recommended with the surplus with the projected surplus. So, if you do not get the tobacco settlement, you will cut elsewhere? If I do not get in other words, if we do not get the tobacco settlement, we will either have to cut the size of the child care initiative or cut elsewhere, or do something else, because I will not just, on my own, get up and propose that we spend the proposed settlement, or part of it, on these programs. I think they are terribly important, but right now we have got other fish to fry. And we have got to make sure the most important thing is to keep this economy growing, to keep disciplined, to keep strong, to do what makes sense. And that is what has gotten us here, DATE of that, and we do not want to forget that. So we do have new spending in our programs, but it is new spending within a context of fiscal discipline.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mara Liasson and Robert Siegel of National Public Radio

text: It is new discipline with the smallest ORG since PERSON was President and the size of it continuing to go down. Federal prosecutors reportedly rejected a plea bargain agreement not long ago with PERSON, with his lawyers at least, that might have guaranteed his imprisonment for life. Evidently they want the death penalty. Is it important to you, say, if he is convicted, that there be an exercise of the ORG death penalty? If he is guilty, he killed a lot of people deliberately, and, therefore, I think it is something that the jury should be able to consider. From my point of view, I approve of the laws that we have in GPE now, the sort of CARDINAL-tiered trial where you determine guilt and then you determine penalty, and I would want to hear all the testimony before I decided how I'd vote in that case. But I do think it should be presented to the penalty phase. Even if you had a guilty plea that as there is no parole in the ORG system guaranteed none and spared any possibility of an acquittal, you would still prefer to reject that plea, to offer the jury the option of the death penalty? I think the jury should have the option. Now, also, as a practical matter, there are not many inmates perhaps he would be one that actually do get life without parole. That is, in a prison system, where you do not want prison riots, you have to reward people who do an extraordinarily good job of being good inmates within the prison system, perhaps the practice of allowing people who have life sentences to be paroled after quite a long period of time is a good one, or, at least, defensible. But juries know that, too. But this was a case where, based on what I know, I would consider it appropriate to present that to the jury. ENTITY, on the NORP financial crisis, a lot of NORP do not understand why taxpayers should help bail out banks and investors in the GPE or GPE or in Europe who took a risk and made some mistakes. Do not they bear some responsibility? Do not they have to take some of the hit? They do bear some of the responsibility, and they should not all be bailed out. And that is one of the most frustrating things about this. On the other hand, what this is about is about rebuilding confidence in the investment climate of these countries.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mara Liasson and Robert Siegel of National Public Radio

text: I do not think they ought to get MONEY unless the governments commit to do things for the future that will mean these banks will have to take a bigger risk, and get their act cleaned up, unless the ORG plan is implemented, and then the GPE and GPE and these other countries come in as a backup. But if we refuse on the front end to do anything, the problem is it could hurt us a lot worse than it could hurt the odd banker that does not get his money back, because if a lot of people start not getting any of their money back, then other people say, Well, I am going to get my money out, and then others say, Well, I am not going to put my money in ; and then all of a sudden the value of the currency goes way down. They do not have any money to buy NORP products and all their products are cheaper, competing against ours and other countries. So we have a big economic interest as well as a huge interest in a stable, democratic Asia. And that is why I think we are doing the right thing. I hope in the State of the Union I can persuade the NORP people that it is the right thing. I want to ask you about Clintonism. We have been hearing a lot about Clintonism lately, a coherent political philosophy that may or may not be identified with you. I think, first of all, it is a very it is a future-oriented political philosophy that attempts to break the logjam between the DATE's and DATE debate of the NORP position that Government is the enemy and the NORP position is, sort of, Government is the solution if we do more of the same; we just need to do more. My position is we need a different kind of Government for a different kind of society and a different kind of world. And we need to focus more on giving people the tools they need to make the most of their own lives, more on being a catalyst for good ideas, more on empowering the disadvantaged, and creating opportunity, enforcing responsibility, building community. I think that is what ORG is about. And I think it will get us to DATE.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mara Liasson and Robert Siegel of National Public Radio

text: You have a budget deficit that is getting smaller, the trade deficit is shrinking, and yet even with a record stock market, virtually full employment, NORP are nervous. In a recent ORG/NBC News poll, CARDINAL of the NORP people say that we are either in a recession or headed toward a recession. Why the angst and why cannot your administration take get any of the credit for this good news? Well, we certainly try to explain to the NORP people that there are some that there is good news. There is been DATE of job growth, which is the longest stretch in the history of the country. The budget deficit's down to PERCENT of GDP, which is extremely low. A couple of factors, I think, trouble NORP. CARDINAL is that there is a lot of churning in the job market. In other words, if you are DATE, you are likely to have had CARDINAL jobs by the time you are DATE. And older people like me take a look at that kind of volatility or some would call it excitement in the job market, and they wonder whether or not this job turnover is going to affect them. People want to know whether or not, CARDINAL, the government's going to stay out of their business, and CARDINAL, whether or not this is going to be good policy that'll enable them to have affordable and available health care. People are concerned about their pensions to a certain extent. There is still you know, we have transitioned from defined contribution or defined benefit to a defined contribution plan. And yet there are still some who are involved with defined, you know, benefits. So there is a variety of reasons why people are uncertain. But people, when they take a hard look at the statistics and the reality, they ought to, you know, I hope it brings them some comfort to know this economy is strong and it is setting all kinds of records. Speaking of the benefits, what did you think of the ORG's deal with ORG, ORG also working on a deal? Should this be a blueprint for other industries? Well, from my perspective, I am glad they were able to settle the deal in an expeditious way. I appreciate the fact that ORG and the ORG are able to come together quickly and come up with an agreement that satisfied both sides. Let me ask you about the record number of GPE exports.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview with Maria Bartiromo on CNBC's Closing Bell

text: Even with that number, you have got an increasing voice in ORG saying, 'Look, we do not think free trade is working.' It seems you cannot even control the NORP in ORG. And what do you say to those people who are trying to put trade barriers in place? Well, I have long worried about protectionism and isolationism here in GPE. We have had periods of protectionism in our past and I am concerned about protectionist sentiment, because I believe that a world that welcomes GPE products and goods and services is beneficial for NORP farmers and manufacturers. In other words, if there is more customers for what we produce here in GPE, the better off the producers will be. It is also good for consumers that we have open markets. In other words, the more options the consumer has, the less inflationary our society can be. And I think it is good when consumers are able to have a variety of choices. And so I it is going to be very important for me to continue to explain the positive side of trade. In other words, people are getting work. There is a lot of people whose jobs depend upon exportation of goods and services. There are people whose jobs benefitted as a result of foreign capital coming into the country. I think about some of the automobile manufacturers in the South. But I understand why people are anxious about trade. People are saying, 'I may lose my job, or somebody else is going to get my job because of free trade.' And what is very important for people like me who believe in markets is CARDINAL, to explain the economic benefits, but also to assure people that there is trade adjustment programs to help people retrain for better jobs that have got stability. Let me switch to housing. We have had a meltdown in housing. Oh, first of all, there is a lot of people who can afford the houses that they live in and they are going to be fine There is no question there are particularly some people on the margin that are going to have to that are defaulted on their loans, and that troubles me. It troubles me because I want people to be able to stay in their homes.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview with Maria Bartiromo on CNBC's Closing Bell

text: And the solution, it seems like to me, is not more government or more regulation, but to help people refinance their homes, is to I have some transparent policies as well as counseling polices that find people, identified people and encouraged them to go to refinance their homes, and to encourage the lenders to be, you know, refinancers. What happened, it seems like to me in the housing, again, I am not an expert, but there was a lot of incentive for people to, you know, buy homes. And so we had a huge supply of homes. And until the supply and demand gets back in balance, you are going to see some softness. There is not a nationwide phenomenon, there are parts of our country that are doing just fine in their real estate markets. And you know, we are paying close attention to it and we are going to make sure that government policy is not counterproductive but consumers can be helped to stay in their homes, for example, through ORG reform. So were the rate cuts enough or would you think to encourage more? Well, I knew you would try to suck me into the dialogue of monetary policy but you know full well that ORG is independent from the president. I never send PERSON instructions, he does not expect me to send him instructions, nor do I publicly comment on what I would like to see done or monetary policy. I can talk about fiscal policy DATE and that is we will keep taxes low and make sure ORG does not overspend the people's money. Let us talk about that in particular, the health care coverage. You vetoed a plan DATE to expand health care coverage for CARDINAL of low income children. First of all, the NORP are misleading people when they say this is a plan to expand health care to CARDINAL of low income children. The plan that I vetoed would have expanded health care coverage to families making MONEY, in some cases. And which would have meant people would have been moving from private insurance to public care. I do support a program that helps poor children. But the program that I vetoed expanded health care, government health care. By the way, just so you know some of the facts I think will interest you. CARDINAL poor children under the program as it exists DATE do not get coverage. And so my first call to ORG is let us make sure they get coverage.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview with Maria Bartiromo on CNBC's Closing Bell

text: Secondly, in some states, like CARDINAL states, the states use the money aimed for poor children, they spend more money on adults than they do on children. So my call to ORG was it you are truly for poor children, like I am, let us make sure the program answers that need, and let us not expand the federal role in health care. See, I believe that for some members, this was an important step toward the federalization of health care. Really fine people believe that the best health care policy is when the federal government runs it. I believe the best health care policy is to take care of those who cannot help themselves, like poor children, and encouraged those in the private sector. I am for private medicine. I want decisions to be being made between doctor and patient, not between people here in GPE, GPE. And so the I am vetoing the bill, working hard to see that it is not overridden, the veto's sustained, and then I will be willing to work with the NORP to focus the program on poor children. CARDINAL NORP and I do admit this was a NORP, say look, all of a sudden you found fiscal discipline now and you veto this, but how come you signed the Farm Bill, you signed the Highway Bill and others, passed by NORP ORG that substantially exceeded your initial target? Well, I would remind that person that over the course of my presidency, we have been able to reduce the federal deficit substantially. As I told you, it is down to PERCENT of GDP, which is historically low, very low. And I was able to do so working with the ORG, and at the same time, fight a war and make sure our kids had the support and troops equipment they needed. In other words, the fiscal policy of low taxes and setting fiscal priorities here in GPE has worked. And we are on our way to balancing this budget and it is going to be very important for ORG not to overspend nor raise taxes. What do you think of Senator PERSON's idea, the kid bond idea? It sounds similar, actually, to your idea of private accounts with ORG. Well, my idea in ORG was is that rather than putting your money into a trust that was not generating a rate of return that was fair, that you ought to be allowed to take some of your money and set it aside in a personal account.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview with Maria Bartiromo on CNBC's Closing Bell

text: In other words, it is setting aside a part of the portion of your contribution in the ORG system, which I think is vastly different from what she proposed. I am not going to interject myself into the presidential campaign yet. You have DATE left in your second term. What are your goals for the economy for the rest of your service here? Well, first is to keep taxes down and keep, you know, and to have good, wise fiscal policy. To work with ORG and say, 'Look, let us set priorities and meet those priorities,' and be willing to use the veto if they want to overspend, which the initial blush looks like they are going to try to do. CARDINAL of the reasons why our DATE growth was good was because of exports. In other words, when we export it means growth in our economy. Continue to work on energy policy that makes us less dependent on foreign sources of energy. And so I have got an important agenda that and win the war on terror and protect the homeland. By the way, one of the best economic measures we can do is make sure we do not get attacked again. As you know, the attacks of DATE crippled our economy for a short period of time. I would not say cripple's not the right word damaged our economy for a short period of time. And you know, and we will keep working night and day to make sure we protect the NORP people. So is ORG off the table at this point or will you try to fix it in the remaining time? You know, I'd like to, but remember, I am the person that has laid this issue out in my State of the Union address and talked specifically about how to address ORG. Whether or not ORG has got the will to step up and try to get something done, I do not know. In spite of all that, there are still all these people and places that have not felt this recovery, that need investments and businesses and jobs and hope. And I believe that we need to convince the NORP business community that these are markets to invest in. And I think we ought to give them the same incentives to invest in poor areas in GPE we give them to invest in poor areas in Latin America or Africa or Asia.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Maria Elvira Salazar of Telemundo Noticiero in Hartford, Connecticut

text: And what incentives can you offer them that are not in place right now? We can offer them tax credits, and we can offer them loan guarantees. And we can offer them modest expenditures of public funds to support these kinds of investments. They will make a big difference. For example, if let us just take a poor neighborhood in GPE or GPE or even here in GPE, where there is a very large NORP population. Let us suppose that we wanted to have a MONEY investment. Under this proposal, if my bills were to become law, they could put MONEY in equity, and they would get a PERCENT tax credit. They could borrow MONEY and have it under a ORG loan guarantee, which would dramatically lower the interest rate. So you would say, okay, you are taking a little bit of a risk investing in a poor area, but we will cut the risk way, way down. Yet a disproportionate number live in poverty, do not have health care, and cannot get a job. Why has the NORP dream eluded them? Well, let me start with the positives. We also have more successful NORP in GPE than ever before, more people like you and the people that work for ORG. We have the lowest unemployment rate we have ever recorded, and we started keeping separate NORP unemployment rates in DATE. Number CARDINAL, a lot of the NORP population of GPE are recent immigrants. Recent immigrants always have more problems with health insurance and with employment. They have not very often mastered English; they often do not have the right contacts. So part of that is inevitable. But there are some other things that I'd like to point out. Because of the family traditions that have been so strong in NORP families, very often the children would leave school early to go to work. And that worked for generation upon generation of NORP families, the people that had been here for DATE. It does not work anymore because if you drop out of high school, your chances of getting a good job with a growing income are very, very small. And the biggest separate social problem we have with NORP in GPE DATE is the dropout rate from school is way too high. DATE, for the first time ever, the graduation rates of NORP and NORP was almost identical. NORP are still dropping out at a very rapid rate. So we have started this NORP education initiative to try to overcome that.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Maria Elvira Salazar of Telemundo Noticiero in Hartford, Connecticut

text: But a lot of it is culture. We must get the message out that this does not work anymore. You cannot do it. You have got to stay in school. And we have to try to get more NORP young people to go on to college. I think that is there are a lot of other things, but that is the single most significant thing that we can do something about is getting people to stay in high school. The fact that we have so many immigrants, they will always have more problems in the beginning, and we just have to integrate them as quickly as we can. I think you have answered my next question, but I want to ask you anyway, and it has to do with youth. In the barrio in GPE, or in any barrio in GPE, there is a DATE boy whose name is PERSON, let us say. His parents struggle to make a living and provide him with a decent education. What message do you have for him, a kid that was born in GPE? My message to him is, if you stay in school and you learn your lessons, no matter how difficult your economic circumstances, you can now go on to college in GPE. We have changed the rules in DATE. If your parents come up with some money, they can get a tax credit back for it. We have more generous scholarships. We have more other funds for you to go. You must stay in school. You can go to college if you stay in school. And if you do, you can make the life that you dream of. Let us talk a little bit about GPE. The democratically elected leaders of CARDINAL Spanish-speaking nations will gather in GPE in DATE. Are you concerned that they are legitimizing PERSON's government? I am a little concerned about it. I think the important thing is, when they go there, I hope that they will reaffirm their support for democracy and for human rights and for a transition to democracy and to an open economy in GPE. As you know, most countries do not agree with our policy on GPE. They think that it hurts the NORP people, that it hurts the NORP business community, and that it does not speed the transition away from PERSON because they think we give him an excuse for the failures of the NORP society, that he can blame everything on us instead of having to take responsibility for himself.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Maria Elvira Salazar of Telemundo Noticiero in Hartford, Connecticut

text: And you know, this argument is now occurring more and more among NORP of all age groups. The most important thing for me, though, is I have every time I have reached out to GPE, and I have tried to increase contacts, to make it easier for people in GPE to send money home, to have direct telephone service, to have more trips to GPE more accessible for people, and you know, something happens. He put journalists in jail, or shot the Brothers to the Rescue people out of the air. I do not care even if they had been inside the territorial waters of GPE, which they were not , there is a convention which binds GPE and GPE which would not have permitted them to be shot down, because they did not present a threat. So all my efforts to change things have been met with a rebuff. And it makes me wonder whether he really wants this to change, because he can always use us as an excuse. But if the countries want to go there and meet, I understand that. If they differ with us on their policy, I respect their right to differ. But I hope when they are in GPE, they will make it clear that they are for democracy and human rights. Have you expressed this to any of the Presidents? I have said that to every one of them that I have seen since they made the decision to go down there. And do you ever foresee normalized relations with PERSON and GPE? I think we could certainly do a lot more for food, for medicine, in other ways, if the circumstances were right. And I think that if there were a clear commitment to a transition to democracy and human rights, which were clear and verifiable, I think that you could see some really dramatic changes. I think you know, if we could just have a commitment to have no more shootings, like the shootings of the airplanes, and to have no more clear oppressings of human rights, it would be easier. I think the NORP people would like to be reconciled with the NORP people. It is painful most of all, I think, for NORP. I come from that group. They tell me CARDINAL more questions. I need to do GPE, and I need to do GPE. I need to do CARDINAL more. Yes, you do them. You do need to do those. GPE GPE is debating MONEY in aid to that country.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Maria Elvira Salazar of Telemundo Noticiero in Hartford, Connecticut

text: Do you foresee, or could GPE be dragged into the civil war that they are living? Well, first of all, let me say we already give a lot of aid to GPE. They are after GPE and GPE, GPE is the third-biggest recipient of NORP aid. I am very concerned about the combination of the narcotraffickers and the people that have been engaged in the civil war down there totally destabilizing GPE. They have already hurt the economy. They have divided the society. They have weakened the country and its government. And it is a big, big country with enormous significance for all of Latin America. If you look at the NORP border, the trouble we have seen there, if you look at all the problems that could be presented with GPE, with the canal going back there, and if you look at all the countries to the south, if you look at GPE, GPE, the problems they have had there, the future of GPE is very, very important. And GPE borders Amazonia, and all the problems that could be created there. So we should be working with them, and we should help them. But, you know, if you look at the whole of the history of GPE's involvement in Latin America, if we were to become directly involved, I think it would ensure a disastrous result for ORG, and people would accuse us of being imperialists in some way. I have worked very hard to reach out to Latin America in a way that no other NORP ENTITY has, at least since President PERSON, to be a friend, to be a partner, to be supportive, and not to be a dictator, not to be an imperialist, not to be abusive in our relationship. So I am going to keep trying to help GPE. But I do not think we should be drawn directly into their conflict, because I think it would boomerang. I do not think it would work, and I think it would actually hurt the cause of freedom and the integrity of governments in Latin America. The GPE PERSON is scheduled to begin exercises DATE off the coast of GPE in GPE. Will you approve the use of live fire? Before that happens, I hope and believe there is a chance that we will reach an accommodation between the ORG and the ORG and the representatives of GPE.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Maria Elvira Salazar of Telemundo Noticiero in Hartford, Connecticut

text: Let me say, as I have said before, I think the fact that there was an agreement made back in DATE, that then the ORG and ORG regularly and flagrantly ignored, treating GPE as if it were still a colony, is really at the root of all this. I think that, as you know, that the ORG has a point, in the sense that if you look at what we had to do in GPE, for example, or what we had to do earlier in GPE, they need to be able to train. They have to be able to do live-fire training somewhere. They need to be able to fly over water. We also have to do landings. You know, when we restored the democratically elected government of GPE, thank God there was no violence, but there could have been. And we have to practice, you know, how do we approach on the shore? On the other hand, we do not want to be in a position of jamming down the throat of GPE, and the people and the elected officials of GPE, CARDINAL bad memory after another of a longstanding relationship where we did not honor our commitments. So what Secretary PERSON has tried to do is take the security report he got saying, you know, we need to use GPE for DATE and the reality of the feelings of the people of GPE and the positions of the leaders, and we are trying hard to work through both of those in a way that there can be an agreement. I think the most important thing is we get out of this treating GPE as if it were literally, for these purposes, a colony of GPE. And if you know, I think the ORG should give them an authoritative vote on whether they want to be a State or continue commonwealth status. I mean, the last vote they had was very close, narrowly for commonwealth, but it was not a sanctioned vote by the ORG. So I have done as much as I could to try to restore the integrity of the relationship between the people and ORG and GPE. And so for me, because I am the Commander in Chief and I also have heavy responsibilities to ensure the preparedness and the integrity of our ORG there is a reason we lost no pilots on GPE. And we try to save lives.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Maria Elvira Salazar of Telemundo Noticiero in Hartford, Connecticut

text: I have got to tell you something, sir. I have been waiting a long time on getting you on this program. I even went down for the big old ENTITY watch when you were over on the Vineyard DATE, and I am sorry I missed you. So let us talk about a couple of things. First of all, you need to know that all the kids over at FAC are looking forward to your coming down with Senator PERSON. And let us talk about this education bill. Even PERSON is calling you the education ENTITY. Well, we have worked very hard on education, and Senator PERSON has had a lot to do with it. A lot of our education initiatives have not attracted a great deal of public notice, maybe because we have been successful in getting bipartisan support for them, for most of them, all but the college loan program. The program to provide middle class college loans at lower interest rates had no NORP support because we took on some organized interest groups. And it is a real tribute to PERSON because he got the expansion of ORG in, he got the national service program in. And this education act we are signing in GPE DATE, or in GPE, has an incredible amount of good things in it. It is a dramatic reform in terms of putting more responsibility back on local school districts, giving them freedom from NORP rules and regulations but giving them very high standards to shoot for. It is a really it is a very modern, exciting, and I think, effective piece of education legislation. I am proud to be signing it. Well, you know, ENTITY, Senator PERSON is not only delighted to have you here signing that particular bill, but as you know, this is the toughest race the Senator has ever faced in DATE. And for many of us in GPE, we are surprised to know that nationally he is CARDINAL of several seats that we are looking at that could be in very serious jeopardy. Your coming out here to help him will be bringing a message to GPE voters that says what? How important is Senator PERSON and his reelection to the completion of your agenda as you go back to GPE? He is terribly important to doing it. And he is important for some reasons that people, I think, may not be aware of in GPE. I mean, the rap that his critics are saying is that, Well, he is been there long enough.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Marjorie Clapprood of WRKO Radio, Boston, Massachusetts

text: But I can tell you, I have been talking around here DATE, just asking people, and there is a general feeling here that of all the people in the ORG, PERSON is one of the CARDINAL or CARDINAL who are most receptive to new ideas, to trying new things, to breaking out in new directions. And if you just look at what we have done in education, we have changed the whole national approach to education. Have national standards, have ORG helping, but give people the freedom at the grassroots level to try new things and to do things that will work. And he is also been instrumental in developing a national apprenticeship program for young people who do not go to college and, as I said, this college loan program. We have had the most impressive set of achievements in DATE in education we have seen in DATE, a lot of cutting-edge, new ideas, and PERSON has done it. The other thing he is very good at that I think people do not appreciate is he is the best NORP legislator at getting NORP to support what he is doing. He is the best at getting bipartisan support. And I think that if the people of GPE know that, they would be more inclined to reelect him, because he is really a very forward-looking Member of the ORG, and we need him back. Well, one of the things that the First Lady said when she was in DATE I was happy to be at the dinner that she hosted for the Senator she went so far as to say that Senator PERSON's opponent, PERSON, is really just another clone for PERSON and another Senator no for you. Are you as worried about that? Do you want to make any predictions on all of these ORG threats that they are going to be taking over the ORG and taking over the ORG this time around? Well, I do not think they will if we can get the facts out there. I mean, we have made the Government work for ordinary NORP. We have passed things like family leave and the PERSON bill and immunizations for all the kids in this country DATE, against ferocious NORP opposition. We have got more highwage jobs coming into the economy in DATE than DATE combined. If we can get the record out, we should be winning seats, not them.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Marjorie Clapprood of WRKO Radio, Boston, Massachusetts

text: But the problem is that they are great talkers, and they promise the Moon, and they will go like robots off of a cliff together. And that is what I am worried about. It is no offense to Mr. PERSON, but they all in DATE of the legislative session up here, we had an important piece of environmental legislation, the Superfund bill to clean up toxic waste dumps. Everybody in GPE was for it. We had the chemical companies, the unions, ORG; they were all for it first time they had ever agreed on anything. There was no one in GPE against it except over CARDINAL NORP Senators who filibustered it to death to keep people like PERSON from coming back to GPE and saying we helped to clean up toxic waste dumps. They were willing to leave the poison in the ground. They killed lobby reform and campaign finance reform. And all the lobbyists were cheering Senator PERSON when he walked off the floor of the ORG and saying how great it was. Now, I do not think the NORP people want to turn the ORG over to them. And especially, I do not think they want to go back to trickle-down PERSON. That is what they have promised to do, you know. They have promised to give us the economic policies that they did in DATE that put New England in the ditch. And I do not think that the people will support it once they know that. Well, you know, one of the things that I loved about your campaign, ORG, was the slogan It is the economy, stupid. And it seems as though, with all the indicators macroeconomically looking so terrific what is the deal with cynical voters? I mean, how do we get this message out? It seems to me that you cannot win for losing, even when everything looks good. And that is that we have had DATE when most wages have been stagnant for TIME and when people have been changing jobs more frequently, so that makes them more insecure. The average DATE, for example, will change jobs CARDINAL, CARDINAL times in a lifetime now. So even though people may say the unemployment rate is dropping and new jobs are coming into GPE, into GPE, there is still an unsettled feeling. A lot of people themselves have not gotten a raise. CARDINAL NORP lost their health insurance DATE; that is why we have to address that.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Marjorie Clapprood of WRKO Radio, Boston, Massachusetts

text: Then there is a political problem, which is that when ORG is in session, particularly with the bitter partisan obstruction we have seen, what tends to get covered is the fights, the bad news, the failures, the process. So a lot of people just do not know the facts about the economy. So what I am going out to do now, in DATE, is to say, Look, we are making Government work for ordinary people. We are bringing the economy back. The world is a more peaceful, more secure place for NORP, with opportunities for prosperity. We should be very upbeat about the future, and we ought to reward the people that are building the future, not reward the people that are tearing it down. Do you have any further comments, other than those that you made on ORG, about talk radio? Do you think that the right-wing conservative bashing of talk radio has done a disservice? It seems to me that is the national pastime of a lot of my colleagues on the air; that is just the get good ratings if you kick PERSON around. Me. Oh, I like you. But generally, I like radio because it is an immediate, it is almost an intimate thing. And people feel that they have a chance to have their say. But a lot of these folks who are on the far right, they never have anybody on that disagrees with them, they never have an honest discussion, and they are not as careful as they ought to be with their facts. I think it is good to have your critics on there and to have honest debates. We should not all agree on everything, and no one in GPE, including the ENTITY, is right about everything. But what I think the NORP people ought to insist on from talk radio is a conversation, not a screaming match, and strict adherence to the facts. That is the only thing that bothers me. I think generally this talk radio phenomenon can be a great instrument in promoting democracy. People feel so isolated from GPE, so isolated from the bureaucracies. A lot of folks even feel isolated from their State capital. So if talk radio makes people feel like they have got a voice, they can be heard, then that is good. And I have got this big problem my mother always said to me, a position that is not articulated ceases to exist. I agree with that. I wanted to ask you a little bit about international affairs, if we can.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Marjorie Clapprood of WRKO Radio, Boston, Massachusetts

text: Coming on the heels now of what looks like a fairly peaceful transition and return of PERSON to power in GPE, you have got an awful lot on your international plate, with the Middle East, with what is happening in GPE, and I understand you are on your way DATE to the signing of the peace accord between GPE and GPE. Do you feel as though you have turned a major corner in your administration in terms of not only the maturity of the ENTITY administration but in public perception finally cutting you a break and saying, You know what, he is doing all right ? I think, first of all, a lot of these problems are very difficult, and they do not yield TIME. And a lot of them are things we have been working on here for DATE. But I am very proud of what our people, particularly our young men and women in uniform, have done in GPE and in the Persian Gulf. I am proud of the role GPE is playing toward peace in the Middle East and in GPE. And I am very proud of the work that Ambassador PERSON did in hammering out this agreement with NORP, which will enable us to avoid a confrontation with them, and enable them to move toward a more normal relationship with GPE and with the rest of the world, and take a major nuclear threat away. But I am feeling good about it. getting our relationship straight with the NORP and reducing the nuclear threat in that part of the world, and toward getting an international economic order set up. We worked on ORG, the Asian Pacific countries, the ORG world trade agreement. And then DATE, we had some good success, as you have pointed out, in GPE and the Middle East and elsewhere. And I am very excited, as I know a lot of people in GPE are, about the moves toward peace in GPE. And we are working hard on that as well. You do not even have time to go bowling anymore. I miss bowling. By the way, I know I heard on your birthday one of your wishes was to break DATE. Did you ever do that?  I am playing pretty well, for me. And if I lowered my handicap when I was ENTITY, the NORP people would never believe that I am working as hard as I am. So I probably should not want to break DATE. It makes you very charming and endearing, because the rest of us can all relate to that. Let me ask you just a couple wacky questions.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Marjorie Clapprood of WRKO Radio, Boston, Massachusetts

text: The thing that I remember most about you from the first time that I heard about the Governor from GPE that wanted to be ENTITY was a picture I saw of you with then-ENTITY PERSON, a personal hero of mine but also someone here from GPE. And I grew up in his hometown of GPE. And I saw that picture recently on sort of a retrospective of your tenure over DATE as ENTITY. And I wondered, from that idealistic young man that you were, to now sitting in FAC and dealing with questions like sending the 82d Airborne down to GPE while PERSON and PERSON and PERSON sat there, making decisions on war and peace, is it everything that you thought it was going to be? I mean, if anything, I am more hopeful, more optimistic about the future of this country than I was before I got here. You never want to say, Quit your bitching. Well, I do want to say that some. I mean, sometimes I think that NORP in this time are a little too prone to see the glass as CARDINAL empty instead of CARDINAL full. Our optimism, our unfailing faith in our ability to make the future better has been one of the great secrets to our successes over DATE. And so I do feel that. I regret that at this moment in our history there is a lot of accumulated cynicism and frustration and that it is, in some ways, more difficult for the ENTITY to communicate directly to the NORP people than it has been in the past, because of all the indirect filters between me and the NORP people. The Presidency is more isolated than I wish it were, partly because of the security concerns that exist in this day and age. But having said all that, it is a joy and an honor to go to work here DATE. And I feel good about the fact that the economy is coming back. I feel good about the fact that we are facing up to problems that have been ignored for DATE and DATE here. I feel good about the fact that we are able to do things like this family leave law and to give tax breaks to working families with children to keep them out of poverty, because I do not think anybody that works full-time with a kid in the house should be there. These are things I take pride in, not for me but for our country.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Marjorie Clapprood of WRKO Radio, Boston, Massachusetts

text: ENTITY, it is DATE to go until the deadline in GPE obviously DATE, the politicians still at loggerheads apparently. What is it that you want them to do now in this make-or-break time? I want them to remember how strongly the people voted for peace and for the Good Friday accords and to find an honorable resolution of the admittedly thorny problems. Because whatever the difficulties of going forward, they are very small compared to the difficulties of letting the peace process fall apart. Now, you say there are thorny problems, and that is the difficulty and especially the problem of decommissioning. Would you be urging ORG to do what NORP are urging GPE to do, to namely sign up to a timetable for disarmament and give a categorical assurance that the ORG will have disarmed completely by DATE? I think that all the parties should fully comply with the terms of the Good Friday accords, and that is what I would say. I think that they all have to find a way we know what the problems, the legitimate problems ORG have with the decommissioning issue. But it is an important part of the Good Friday accords, so there has to be a resolution of it that enables the leadership of the NORP, Mr. PERSON and the others who have fought for peace, to survive, to sustain their position, and to go forward and get everybody on their side to honor the Good Friday accords, too. They can find a way to do this if they decide that the price of failure is far higher than the price of compromise. And I think there is a good chance they will do it; even if it is TIME, I do. Their position has been that there has to be guns handed over, actual hardware, before ORG can go into government. Do you think they should be considering moving ahead on the basis of pledges rather than actually looking for the armaments? Well, I believe that on that score, Mr. PERSON is satisfied in these talks with whatever commitment is made, and I think they should give it a chance to work. CARDINAL thing I would say to the NORP is that they can always walk away from this if the commitments are not made at a later date. And they should keep in mind they can bring this down at any time by simply walking out if the commitments are not kept.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Devenport of the British Broadcasting Corporation in Westport, Connecticut

text: So I think that if Mr. PERSON can be satisfied and they can work it through, then I would hope the NORP would support him and give him a chance give this thing a chance to work. Now, this political deadline is also coinciding with the DATE deadline that there is in GPE of the GPE march. As we speak, an announcement on the GPE march is imminent. There are extremely strong indications that the NORP will not be allowed to go down the NORP section of FAC. How concerned are you about what the impact of a refusal to let the NORP go down FAC could be, both on the streets and on the political process? Well, as an outsider, you know, to me this looks like the most difficult of decisions because it is there is enormous emotional content on both sides. It is not just a matter of a lot of people walking on a certain road. And I think however it is resolved DATE, the most important thing is that the parties themselves try to find a larger, omnibus resolution for this that reflects the spirit of the Good Friday accords. Keep in mind, I mean, the spirit of the Good Friday accords is that both sides should have respect for and get respect from one another, and that no one should have to give up his or her heritage or traditions, but they should be pursued with some sensitivity to how others feel as well. So I think that they are in a terrible bind now because the PERSON deadline is coming up against the negotiation deadline. And so, however it is resolved, I think that what the leaders should be thinking about is, what is the long-run resolution of this? How can we show one another the necessary respect and sensitivity that will put this marching issue in the context of the commitment of the Good Friday accords, which is to push toward reconciliation and equality within the principle of consent? At the time of the DATE agreement, you waited up through TIME in GPE, inside FAC, seeing how the negotiations were working out. You went on the phone personally and spoke to the main parties and tried to coax them forward. DATE, with a new deadline, are you willing to do the same, to intervene personally? You know, this means a lot to me. It means a lot to the NORP people.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Devenport of the British Broadcasting Corporation in Westport, Connecticut

text: We have CARDINAL of NORP and NORP who are deeply invested emotionally, and many of them financially, in GPE, and would like to be more involved. And I also believe, as I have said many times, that if this can be resolved if we can get over this next hurdle and go forward I think it will give courage to the advocates of peace in the face of religious and ethnic problems in other parts of the world. You know, we are just getting off the ground with our efforts in GPE. There are many difficulties there, and the accumulated grievances there, from mass killing and mass uprooting, are deeper, if you will, just in terms of human loss than all the things that have happened in GPE. But people have this sense that the divisions in GPE go back such a long time, that if they can be overcome, I think it would give great heart to the proponents of peace in the Balkans and Africa and the Middle East, because the new Prime Minister is about to announce a government there; we have a chance again to make progress and peace in the Middle East. And I think that from my point of view, as someone who is interested in not only the country of my roots but the rest of the world, I think that it is hard to overstate; it is hard to overstate the impact a positive or a negative outcome could have on such actions in the rest of the world. Finally, ENTITY, there is only so much that you or, indeed, the NORP and NORP Prime Ministers can do to coax people along. Is this the time when GPE political leaders have to stand on their own CARDINAL feet? Well, I think they can know that we can coax them, and we can stand with them, and we can support them, and we can bring them benefits in all kinds of ways after this is resolved. But in the end, the leaders have to decide. Their people have voted for peace. Somebody if there is the necessary commitment given by all sides, and then, later, any of those commitments are not kept, this thing can always be brought down because the commitments were not kept.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Devenport of the British Broadcasting Corporation in Westport, Connecticut

text: ENTITY, I want to ask you, first of all, your thoughts on the first CARDINAL of play. Well, you forget how many NORP are in the ORG now. Between PERSON and PERSON and PERSON, they have got a good team. So it took a while for our guys to kind of get into rhythm, but we are so much deeper that over time you get a sense they are going to wear them down. I do not think it will be close in the second CARDINAL. ORG, ENTITY, has undergone a culture change. They bottomed out a little bit in DATE with the ORG, and then Coach PERSON came aboard and really turned it around. Well, obviously, Coach PERSON is one of the greatest coaches of all time. He knows how to bring together folks to think like a team. And obviously, the talent that we have got at this point is unbelievable. So there is no reason we should not bring home the Gold. You really get a sense of how proud they are to represent GPE, and I think they are going to conduct themselves really well in GPE. CARDINAL of the subjects of great debate of late, started by CARDINAL PERSON, was the fact that he feels that the present constitution of the team would beat the DATE original version. Can you weigh in on that argument for us? I was around in DATE. I was a ORG fan, so I have got to go with the original ORG. And I suspect that PERSON and Sir PERSON and others would point out they were probably never down at any point in any of their games. But this is a great team, unbelievable talent, and PERSON is a competitor, so you expect him to do a little trash talking whenever the opportunity arises. Everybody knows that. And you are involved in coaching your daughters. We saw ORG win by a big margin TIME. How would you characterize your experience in coaching your CARDINAL daughters? Well, first of all, I want to congratulate the women's team. They are going to be as dominant, if not more dominant, I think in the Olympics. And wonderful young women; they are great role models for my daughter. And I had a chance to say hello to them before this game started. As you know, coaching kids, your heart is out there on the floor with them.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Jones of ESPN2 During a United States-Brazil Men's Basketball Game

text: Heading into DATE, beyond your immediate goals for the rest of your term, what do you think are the CARDINAL or CARDINAL top domestic challenges facing the country? I think the aging of GPE and the children of the country. It is ironic that we seem to be growing at both ends. We are going to double the number of people DATE, and yet, we have the largest group of schoolchildren in our country's history in our schools, the first group bigger than the baby boomers, and they are much, much more diverse. They come from more different ethnic and racial and religious backgrounds. And I think that dealing with them are the CARDINAL biggest things that ought to be on the front burner. I also believe that, related to that, obviously, as you have heard me say many times, is the challenge of continuing to grow the economy while reaching out into poor areas, continuing to improve the environment, and paying the debt off. ENTITY, CARDINAL of the things I have noticed about these celebrations that ORG, you, and the First Lady are planning is that it is propagating the myth that DATE is the start of DATE and DATE. Are you guilty of creating that erroneous impression? I mean, I think basically, by common consent, everybody decided that we ought to celebrate DATE on DATE, even though most of the strict correctionists say that it is DATE. Well, apparently, that was the prevailing view among the experts, but the people have expressed a different wish, so we are going with the folks. We have got a democracy here, and that is the way we are going. It will be nice for me. Maybe I can do it twice, and I will be a ENTITY of CARDINAL millennial changes. Well, looking ahead into DATE, whenever it begins, where do you see the power of the Presidency itself evolving? But I think it will always at least for the future that I can foresee will continue to be an extremely important office. I think that a lot of the executive actions will be important, along with getting along with ORG. I think that building partnerships with the private sector will become more important. It will become more important to mobilize the NORP people and to organize them to meet the challenges in the future the way we have done.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: For example, maybe a good example would be the way we have worked on wiring the schools, where we did the main Government thing we did was to change the law so that we have this E-rate now in poorer schools and hospitals. You mean wiring for the Internet? Poorer schools and hospitals can get a discount rate. Then we go out and try to hustle up all the equipment and the Internet connections and get everybody to do that. So I think you will see a lot more of that. The other thing I think you will see is, I believe the world is growing ever more interdependent, so I think the ENTITY, in order to effectively lead the world, will have to be an increasingly effective negotiator, conciliator, bringing people together, working people together. And I think it will be just as important DATE for GPE to be involved in the rest of the world as it is now. But I think it will be an increasingly interdependent world that will require powers of persuasion and not just unilateral power. DATE is also, as you well know, DATE of your Presidency. Do you find that in any way liberating to try and do things that you were not able to do in DATE of your Presidency? I find it it is concentrated my attention and my energies and, obviously, since I am not running, I could do things in DATE that might be difficult to do otherwise. But if you go back, I mean, we have taken a lot of controversial decisions. That is CARDINAL of the reasons we lost the ORG in DATE; we took on the gun lobby and the health care lobby and the deficit issue at the same time, and it was more than the system could bear, I think. But I do think that I am acutely mindful of the fact that I have DATE left, and that I need to be out there squeezing the most out of DATE. And I need to get as much done as I can for the NORP people, to try to leave our country in the best possible shape so that the next President and the next ORG will be even freer than they are to basically look with a visionary eye to the future and take on the big issues. That is the theme that I had DATE in GPE; that is the theme that I try to echo everywhere.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: I believe that this really is the only time in my lifetime we have had so much prosperity, social cohesion, and national self-confidence, with the absence of internal crisis or external threat. I will get as much done on these big challenges as I can. But after I am out of office and there is a new team in, I still think it is very important that they keep the NORP people focused on these big issues in DATE, because a society rarely has the luxury of having the tools and the space to deal with these longterm challenges that we now have. And I think it is very important that we seize it. Let me ask you CARDINAL specific, if I may, on the question of gays in the military. As you no doubt know, the First Lady DATE was critical of the do not ask, do not tell policy. You were not going to institute that at the beginning of your Presidency, anyway. And what do you think of what the First Lady said DATE? First of all, I am quite sympathetic with what she said. I think that was the position that both of us brought to ORG. The reason that I went for do not ask, do not tell is that it is all I could do because I had a clear signal from the ORG that if I implemented my policy, they would reverse it by overwhelming majorities. I did not implement do not ask, do not tell until the ORG voted CARDINAL-32 against the policy that I wanted. For me, what is important is that the policy, as implemented, does not work as I announced it and as the leaders of our military at that time in DATE pledged to implement it. I can only hope this last brutal beating death of a gay soldier will give some sobering impetus to a reexamination about how this policy is implemented and whether we can do a better job of fulfilling its original intent. Let me remind you that the original intent was that people would not be rooted out; that they would not be questioned out; that this would be focused on people's conduct, and if they did not violate the code of conduct, and they did not tell, that their comings and goings, the mail they got, the associates they had, that those things would not be sufficient to kick them out of the military or certainly subject them to harassment.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: So what I would like to do is to focus on trying to make the policy that we announced back in DATE work the way it was intended to, because it is way it is out of whack now, and I do not think any serious person can say it is not. How are you going to do that, sir? Well, we are working with the ORG now to do it. Now, as for but I do not have any problem with what she says, because that is after all, that is what I said back in DATE, and if anybody you know, if there is a sense in the ORG or in the next ORG that that ought to be done, then maybe together they will have enough votes to do it. You mentioned earlier the importance of future Presidents becoming even more mediators and conciliators on the world scene. DATE, of course, GPE and GPE are going to be at FAC. And I know you told us, at the news conference, you have taken a blood oath to avoid discussing details of those long-stalled talks, the renewal of them, but how do you plan just in general, since you do not want to go into details how do you plan to get this process moving and keep it moving when you get these gentlemen sitting down again? Well, I want to get them together, let them talk, and get them to try to agree on an agenda and a timetable. They know what the issues are, and they know what the options are for resolving the issues. And my experience has been that competent people and you are dealing with CARDINAL highly competent people here; I mean, these people are good in what they do in representing the interests of their countries, and that when they do not go into these negotiations without some idea about where they want to finish and some idea about where they will have to give, and whether the other person will give, and how it will all play out. So on the other hand, it is difficult, but not as complex, in my view, as the NORP negotiations with GPE. So I would like to see them get together, talk together, get to know each other a little better, and agree on an agenda and a timetable, and then take DATE off and go back and meet with their respective teams to decide where they are going to start and where they are going to stop, and come back here and just look to burn through it, just keep going until we get the thing done.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: I think because both leaders, for different reasons, finally have this sense of urgency, and I think they should have a sense of urgency. And I think they know that the enemies of the peace process are gearing up; they want to try to derail it, and not just for the NORP. I think that they know that there is a sense of hope and possibility now, and I think they believe that Prime Minister PERSON is committed to trying to resolve all this, just like he said he was. ENTITY, is there any doubt in your mind, sir, that GPE is responsible for the listening device that was discovered at ORG? And to what extent are you disturbed by it? Do not we all do the same things, spy on each other? I think when we have always taken spying seriously and taken appropriate action, and I think they will take appropriate action in this regard. And I have no reason to believe that the press accounts on this are not accurate. You must be concerned, though, about this big security breach in ORG. Well, I certainly wish it had not happened, but I think they learned something about this. I think now they will figure out how to deal with this technology, and it will not happen again. And I think we just have to look, the consequences of all this, while certainly not good, are not as dire as they were in DATE of the cold war when both of us were spying on each other in a much more sweeping way. And we had ways of dealing with it. And there is sort of an established protocol for dealing with this kind of thing, and I think we ought to do it. And the main thing we ought to do is learn whatever we can from the incident. How did they do this? How did they get away with it? How can we prevent it from happening again? What effect will it have on NORP relations with GPE? Based on what I now know, I think we should proceed where it is in our interest to do so in our relations with GPE; and where we have differences of opinion, we ought to proceed to articulate them. You cannot let every spy case affect the larger national interests in the country. Based on your own experiences over DATE, going back to your first campaign, to what extent do you think a politician's private life should become part of the public record? I think I will let the press and the people decide that. I think let me say it in a different way.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: I think that what I have seen too often is that the politics of personal destruction become the preferred option only when people think they cannot win the old-fashioned way; they cannot win on the issues or whatever. Now, a person I am not talking about whether somebody's robbed a bank or something like that, but I think that the pendulum swung pretty far over in the last CARDINAL or CARDINAL elections, and I think it is swinging back now. And I think that is what the voters are saying, and they will try to get it right. But something ought to be genuinely relevant, and we ought to not just target people for no good reason and just pound on them and use that because they could not win the old-fashioned way. I think that both the politicians and the press should be mindful of that. You know, DATE DATE, we had DATE where this sort of thing was all the rage, completely dominated the political debate. And these things come and go, and the underlying health of our democracy and the common sense of our people have always been enough to see us through, and I think they will be here. What do you make of the recent statement by PERSON that he thinks you ought to get right with the law by admitting in a public way that you were not truthful in your statements under oath? I am not sure that I know what to make of Mr. PERSON. You know, he is giving interviews. He is doing talk shows. Why do you think he is still pursuing this after he is resigned his office? I just do not think I can serve any useful purpose by commenting on it now. Maybe I should follow his lead; when I do not have a job, I can comment on it more. Speaking of that, as we wind up here, besides getting your Presidential library off the ground, what is PERSON going to do with the rest of his life? Well, I hope I will be a member of the ORG spouses club. That is one of the things I really hope I will be. And I say that we are laughing, but I am dead serious about that. I want to do what I can to help PERSON. And getting this library and public policy center up and going and having it continue the best missions of my Presidency I think will be quite time consuming. I hope I will have a little more time for my family and my friends, but I still want to be a good citizen.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: I really admire what PERSON's done with his life. I would not necessarily choose the same endeavors, although I have supported ORG, and I certainly believe that if someone needed me in the future to monitor an election or something like that, I ought to be willing to do it. But the main thing I want to say is that he has said the life he has lived has been a life of service, and he said he is also had a very interesting life. I mean, he is had time to go climb up to the base camp of Mount Everest; he goes fishing and does the things that he loves to do; he goes skiing. But he has lived a life of service. And he has recognized that it is an incredible gift to have the chance to be President and that, when you have this gift for DATE, you learn things; you know things; you have a perspective that no one else has the chance to develop. And you cannot just walk away from it and not at least make yourself available. If people do not want you to do anything, that is CARDINAL thing. But at least you ought to be available for public service. And PERSON has lived a life of public service. I admire that, and I hope that when I leave here, I will be able to do a lot of the personal things I am interested in but, fundamentally, help in a way. I do not want to be under foot for the next President. I do not want to get in anybody's way, but I do think there is a lot of good things I can do for the world and for our country, and I intend to try to do what I can. Finally, sir, I know it is DATE away, but what advice do you have for your successor and your successors as the last ENTITY of DATE? What thoughts do you have to pass on to them? I think it is very important for a ENTITY to have a sense of history and a sense of the future. You have to know where your country is at this moment in our journey. You have to know what the lives of the NORP people are like. Then you have to have a vision of what you think it ought to be.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: And once you do that, once you are grounded in the facts and the history and you have a vision of what you think you ought to be, then you need to have a lot of ideas and a lot of energy and a lot of interpersonal skills, and you just need to go to work DATE and never forget your mission, because all the pressures, in political life, on the Chief Executive is at the center of the vortex of all of these things are designed to make you forget your mission. And those who remember their mission and stay on it tend to do very well, even under the most adverse circumstances. You know, PERSON once said in the Civil War, he said, My policy is to have no policy; I am controlled by events. And to some extent, that was true. I am going to save the ORG; if I have to burn every wheat field in this country and if I have to give up my own life to do it, we will not be split. Okay, so he knew where he was in history. You know, if you listened to him, he talked about PERSON a lot. He had this sense of he knew about the future. He signed the Morrill Land Grant Act. He was all for the railroads and the public improvements. He had a lot of imagination about the future, PERSON did, and he said, There will not be any future unless we hold together. No, that is my policy, and I am willing to try anything or anybody or any general to get it done. He was grounded in history. He had the vision of the future. He used to say he kept TIME. My office in FAC on the second floor is in ORG's waiting room, which was later ORG through PERSON. But PERSON used to keep TIME with people that wanted a job in a post office or something, because he said he wanted to be reminded on a regular basis of what the daily concerns of people were, and he wanted the war to be over so everybody could be restored to pursuing those DATE concerns. You have got to understand your country's history, have some idea of your country's future, have a vision of where you want it to go, come up with a set of ideas and a good team, and just pursue it with all the energy and focus you can and have a good time doing it. Do not forget the mission; do not forget who you work for.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller and Peter Maer of CBS Radio in Orlando, Florida

text: ENTITY, let me start by thanking you very much for granting this interview. I wonder if we could start with a little bit of the news of DATE. DATE you issued a written statement expressing deep regret for the deaths at FAC. But the word apologize did not appear in that statement. Is there a reason for that, that you drew a distinction between expressing regret and apologizing? Well, for me, now, other than that I told them to try to draw the statement up based on what we actually knew about the facts. And I worked very closely with or our people have with ORG. We want to be responsive to the people there. And I hope the statement will be taken well by the people of GPE as a genuine expression of regret about what happened. On another issue, there is a story now that a ORG pilot may have been shot down and may be held in GPE. Do you have any information that leads you to believe that there are NORP held POW in GPE? Well, I think the most I should say about this now is that in this particular case, and in this case only, I reviewed the evidence that we had, and we concluded that we should take him off the killed-in-action list and put him on the missing list, which means, obviously, that we have some information that leads us to believe that he might be alive. What does GPE do about it? Well, now that we have some information, we will begin well, we have already begun working to try to determine whether, in fact, he is alive; if he is, where he is; and how we can get him out. Because, since he was a uniformed service person, he is clearly entitled to be released, and we are going to do everything we can to get him out. If GPE was holding an NORP, they could not use it as an issue with GPE unless they let us know they had somebody. Why would they hold somebody and not let us know about it? Would that be to their advantage? That is why we did what we did on the classification. We have enough information that makes us believe that at least he survived his crash, at least that that is a possibility, and that he might be alive. And I thought, in fairness to his family and everyone else involved, based on a review of the information and ORG recommendation, we should change the status.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller of CBS Radio in Dover, New Hampshire

text: But that is all we know, and I do not want to raise false hopes to either. Along the same lines, do we now know for certain that PERSON was behind the attack on the GPE Cole? I cannot say that. I can we do believe he was behind some other attacks on our people and that people affiliated with him have been involved in other attacks. But we are investigating this. We are still running down some of the leads. We are still doing some of the work. I think that we will know, and I think that GPE will take appropriate action. That is, I have absolutely no doubt that President-elect PERSON will continue to pursue the investigation and, when the evidence is in, will take appropriate action. And when that happens, I will support him in doing so. And lastly, on a bit of domestic politics, do you think that Senators would have a good reason not to vote for PERSON for Attorney General because he blocked your nomination of PERSON? Well, first, I think that it was a terrible mistake by the ORG to do it, to do it on a strict party-line vote, which required them to get some NORP to change their position, including the other Senator from GPE, who had introduced Judge PERSON to ORG, and the Senators on ORG who had voted his nomination out positively to the floor. I am going to follow my policy here. You know, I will be an ex-President when this is done, and I do not believe I should be commenting for some period of time on public affairs, plus which my wife is a Senator. She has to vote on it. So I am going to let she can speak for herself, and the other NORP and NORP will speak for themselves. I do not think I should say more. I have known Senator PERSON a long time. I know he is genuinely very, very conservative, and that is what is in his heart. But I did not think this was about that, and it surprised and profoundly disappointed me. I thought that with DATE left, you might speak out with a little more reckless abandon than usual. Look, I need my Miranda warnings when I talk to you guys, you know. I cannot even make a joke in GPE without having it blown out of proportion. Well, as long as you raised that issue, were you trying to say that you question the legitimacy of PERSON election?
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller of CBS Radio in Dover, New Hampshire

text: I have said clearly that I agree with exactly what Vice President PERSON said, that in this country we observe the principle of judicial review. ORG has ruled, and the rest of us have to accept it. And that confers, in a legal sense, a literal legal sense, that confers legitimacy. But I did not say anything different than I have always said; all the NORP were disappointed that the votes were not counted. And I was trying to pay a little homage to PERSON in his hometown of GPE, with a lot of his family and friends there, by saying you know, he did, I think, did a very good job running the Vice President's campaign. They did win the popular vote. We were having a good time. Again, let us look back at your DATE in office, ENTITY. After you were inaugurated in DATE, how long do you think it took you to get up to speed as ENTITY? Well, I would say there has there is a different answer to that depending on what the issue the question is. For example, I think that the issues that I talked about DATE when I reviewed our domestic record on social policy, I think we were ready from DATE. I think we were and I think part of that was the fact that I'd been a Governor for DATE, that I'd been through a tough economic period, had a clear economic philosophy, had worked on education and welfare reform and crime and the environment. Part of it was the fact that I'd had the opportunity to represent the Governors with ORG and the ORG on many issues. On foreign policy, I think I was up to speed on some things and had to learn a lot on others, and I tried to be a quick study. On the ways of GPE, I think it took us probably, you know, even as much as DATE, DATE, before we really had a good feel for some of the rather different ways in which the town works and the ways in which what a President does and says communicates itself to the other decisionmakers and to the larger NORP public in a way that was quite different than had been my experience as Governor.
label: dialogic

metadata.title: Interview With Mark Knoller of CBS Radio in Dover, New Hampshire

text: So I did have a lot to learn about that, and I worked hard at it, and I think it is interesting; I was laughing DATE with PERSON, to illustrate the point we had our roughest political problems in DATE, but if you look back on DATE, some of the most important and, I believe, most fundamentally sound decisions were made in DATE. We passed the first big first we passed the economic plan, which included, among other things, the empowerment zones and the earnedincome tax credit and all the things that got rid of the deficit, as well. And then we passed the family medical law. We passed the Brady law. We passed the crime bill. We passed NAFTA. You know, we did a phenomenal number of things in DATE, substantively.
